title: Understanding Postcoital Bleeding
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value: Postcoital bleeding is vaginal bleeding that occurs after sexual intercourse. It is not part of a menstrual period.

items: The amount of bleeding can range from light spotting to heavier bleeding
It can happen after vaginal penetration, including sex toys or fingers
It can occur at any age

content.value: Many causes are benign, but postcoital bleeding should be checked, especially if it happens more than once.
Postcoital bleeding is often painless, but some people may also experience discomfort or pain during or after sex.
Pain may occur if the cause is related to:

items: Vaginal dryness or thinning of tissues
Conditions affecting the cervix or pelvis

content.title: Reminder
content.description: If bleeding is accompanied by pain, pelvic discomfort, unusual discharge, or bleeding at other times, medical assessment is important.

sections.buttonLabel: Where Does the Bleeding Come From?
sections.cardTitle: Where Does the Bleeding Come From?

content.value: Postcoital bleeding usually comes from the vagina or cervix.
Bleeding may result from friction or small tears in the vaginal tissues.

items: Lower oestrogen levels (e.g., after menopause or while breastfeeding)
Use of objects that may irritate the vaginal lining

content.description: Minor surface tears often settle on their own, but persistent pain or bleeding should be checked.

content.value: Bleeding from the cervix is often light but may still need assessment.

items.title: Cervical Ectropion
items.content: Glandular cells from inside the cervix are present on the outer surface and can bleed easily with contact. This is common in younger people, during pregnancy, or with hormonal contraception.

items.title: Cervical Polyps
items.content: Small, usually benign growths that can bleed when touched.

items.title: Cervicitis
items.content: Inflammation of the cervix, sometimes due to infection (including STIs). Treatment depends on the cause.

items.title: Cervical Cancer
items.content: Uncommon, but postcoital bleeding can be a symptom. Screening reduces risk, but no test completely eliminates it, so persistent bleeding should always be assessed

items: Very heavy bleeding (soaking through pads/tampons quickly or feeling dizzy or faint)
Bleeding after sex with severe pelvic pain, fever, or foul-smelling discharge
Signs of infection or feeling unwell with bleeding

content.title: When to Arrange Prompt Medical Review
content.description:
Any bleeding after menopause

Bleeding after sex that happens more than once

New or unusual vaginal bleeding at any age

sections.buttonLabel: What to Track Before Your Appointment
sections.cardTitle: What to Track Before Your Appointment

content.value: Bringing notes can help your doctor understand your symptoms more clearly.

items.title: When the bleeding happens
items.description: After every time you have sex or only sometimes, and where you are in your cycle (if still having periods)

items.title: How much bleeding occurs
items.description: Spotting, light bleeding, or heavier flow

items.title: Pain during or after sex
items.description: Where the pain is and how long it lasts

items.title: Other symptoms
items.description: Unusual discharge, odour, pelvic pain, fever, or urinary symptoms

items.title: Contraception and medications
items.description: Specially hormonal contraception, HRT, or blood thinners

items.title: Recent changes
items.description: New partner, recent STI risk, menopause status
Use a water-based lubricant if vaginal dryness is a problem
Vaginal moisturisers or prescribed vaginal oestrogen can help dryness after menopause (speak to a clinician first)
